subject: Re: Ant & JUnit - using properties
msgSnippet: ... [...] ... As answered before, a good way to achieve this is to have your test read e.g. test.properties and your and build procedure prepares that file.
messageBody:
Vladimir Blagojevic wrote:

> Hi,
>
> I would like to invoke my unit test from ant and include java style
> properties that are accesible from the Junit test code. For example, the
> file test_case1.properties includes:
>
> user.login=vladimir
> user.pass=junit
>
[...]
> As mentioned before properties should be accesible programatically within
> test case java code:
>

As answered before, a good way to achieve this is to have your test read
e.g. test.properties and your and build procedure prepares that file. That
way you have complete control over test's behavious in your build script.

E.g.

// test code
ResourceBundle b = ResourceBundle.getBundle("test"); // hardcoded

// invoke ant
ant -Dtest.property.file=mytest.properties test

// in build.xml
<copy file="${test.property.file}" tofile="test.properties" />

Now you have mytest.properties copied over test.properties which is read by
your unit test code.
